docs.lead_paragraph: THE Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. set forth the goal. Civil rights and union membership were to be intertwined. The labor movement, Dr. King wrote in 1958, ''must concentrate its powerful forces on bringing economic emancipation to white and Negro by organizing them together in social equality.'' That happened in the 1960's and 1970's. But then unions lost bargaining power and members. And while labor leaders called attention to the overall decline, few took notice that blacks were losing much more ground than whites.

headline.main: For Blacks, A Dream In Decline

docs.snippet: The number of blacks in unions has fallen much more quickly than the number of whites since 2000.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: AMERICAN FEDERATION OF LABOR-CONGRESS OF INDUSTRIAL ORGANIZATIONS

docs.lead_paragraph: The block of 26th Street between 10th and 11th Avenues is an oasis of fine art and even finer footwear, hardly hospitable ground for a dance company. But the Cedar Lake Ensemble, a fledgling contemporary ballet company, possesses one thing most dance companies do not: money. The scarcity of money has assumed somewhat mythic proportions in the dance world, but funds are not necessarily the key to happiness. Despite offering its dancers benefits most only dream of -- year-round work, respectable salaries and health insurance -- the company has lost a number of members, and the atmosphere at its elegant new Chelsea home seems strangely choked.

headline.main: They're in the Money; Cedar Lake Ensemble Has a New Home and Some Old Problems

docs.abstract: Profile of Cedar Lake Ensemble, fledgling contemporary ballet company that, despite ample funding from Nancy Walton Laurie, niece of Wal-Mart founder Sam Walton, and new theater, rehearsal studio and offices on West 26th Street, is struggling to keep dancers; former dancer Dario Vaccaro and costume designer Robert Rosenwasser comment; people who have worked with Cedar Lake describe environment as corporate, noting that dancers were given two pages of rules and are fined for variety of reasons; photos (M)
docs.snippet: The Cedar Lake Ensemble, a fledgling contemporary ballet company, possesses one thing most dance companies do not: money.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: It appears that Florida is poised to contract out Medicare to private insurance companies. Nowhere in your article is improved patient care mentioned, only proposed savings to the health care system. Florida's plan puts the cart before the horse. Many Americans currently on private health plans are dissatisfied with the services they have received. Many studies have shown that private health insurance is invariably more expensive to administer. It appears the most cost-efficient health insurance in this country is actually government-sponsored.

docs.lead_paragraph: In Japan, Aflac is a major supplier of health and life insurance, covering one in every four people. This market accounts for 70 percent of Aflac's operating earnings. In the United States, Aflac is a duck. Despite its 50-year history as a provider of supplemental health and life insurance, Aflac barely registered with Americans until they heard the word squawked by a duck voiced by the comic Gilbert Gottfried in commercials that began running in 2000. According to the Bantam Group, a research firm, 91 percent of Americans are familiar with the Aflac brand, but fewer than 6 percent of working Americans are customers, and only 10 percent of all Americans know what the company, based in Columbus, Ga., does.

headline.main: SATURDAY INTERVIEW -- With Daniel P. Amos and Paul S. Amos II; Big in Japan, But Mostly A Duck Here

docs.snippet: Despite its 50-year history as a provider of supplemental health and life insurance, Aflac barely registered with Americans until the "Aflac duck" came along.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''U.S. Gives Florida a Sweeping Right to Curb Medicaid'' (front page, Oct. 20): Health insurance is insurance. We do not know when we will need health care, or how much. The Bush administration plan reduces the insurance function of Medicaid and makes it more of a defined contribution saving plan. Insurance policies have limits, but the new Medicaid proposal has much more rigid limits than typical health insurance. Since only the wealthy can afford to self-insure, everyone else is left at risk. That risk is why we have insurance. Reduced insurance coverage will increase the cases of extreme loss resulting in bankruptcy. Yet the Bush administration has also reduced access to bankruptcy.
